text: Nothing against sage grouses, famous grouses, or grouses anonymous! I just had to pick a mildly obscure critter as an example.

But I also wrote this, which is another way to critique what Silicon Valley has become/given us/made us, though I came over to this site because @@8885  reminded me and maybe this is less relevant here? lithub.com/rebecca-soln...
Meanwhile, I've been writing things. The latest is this: www.lrb.co.uk/the-paper/v4...

I aspire to spend more time here and less on those other sites, but apparently BlueSky is not compatible with my older version of Safari and I'm now faced with what might just be Updatapalooza but could be Updatarmageddon. Meanwhile have a bluebelly lizard in Nevada.
Not doing social media on my phone has been my best attempt to set limits..... It's MacBook or nothing.

I like him but I didn't like framing the transition as loss. There's not only all the extraction and processing of fossil fuel to escape in all the spaces they take up, but so much to gain from radical reductions in air pollution and all the other forms of poison we've more or less normalized...

I would like to hang out here more (and less on the place the white supremacist guy owns) but I can't get images or the image accompanying a link to show up here, and that's quite limiting. What am I missing (using this on Safari)?

Billionaires “are behemoths, and they mostly use their outsize power in ugly ways – both in how much they consume and how much they influence the world’s climate response” - brilliant piece here by @@2482  www.theguardian.com/commentisfre...
I wrote a thing. About how terrible billionaires are for their direct impact but also their anti-democratic power, mostly used in the worst ways.... www.theguardian.com/commentisfre...

From @@2482 on climate doomerism: “People assume you can’t be hopeful and heartbroken at the same time, and of course you can… Hope is not happiness or confidence or inner peace; it’s a commitment to search for possibilities.” www.theguardian.com/commentisfre...

Last week on Climate One, the iconic @@2482 joined Ariana Brocious for a wide-ranging discussion of the climate movement, women's rights, and why it's not too late to save the world. Their conversation is now streaming on all major podcast platforms.
Thanks and wish me luck!
And oh my was that a mangled mixed metaphor! Forgive me; first cup of tea.
Ooh, still learning to post links here so there's something to see: www.theguardian.com/commentisfre...

Mostly I write about climate and feminism, but maybe the gun cult is kind of the opposite of both those things. The fact that guns don't make their owners safer, because the person you're most likely to kill with a gun is yourself is striking.... www.theguardian.com/commentisfre...

This was their cover story in 2014 when I was the first woman to write the Easy Chair column (which was ridiculous because it debuted in 1851). I did a bunch of feminist writing there, and then #metoo was a bridge too far for the boss and the ship turned around. harpers.org/archive/2014...

Thanks and yeah! Sometimes it had an impact, sometimes it didn't, sometimes people didn't understand how impact works, which is to say often in ways that not instant, quantifiable, and predictable, but matter anyway.
Thank you! Been going after that for a while.   www.newstatesman.com/environment/...

This week on Climate One legendary writer, historian, and activist @@2482 sits down with Climate One co-host Ariana Brocious to discuss the new anthology she co-edited, Not Too Late, and how her life's path brought her to the climate movement.
link.chtbl.com/G-jyp7Ls?sid...

The world will eventually run out of fossil fuels, so our choice is really between stopping their use on our own terms now or being forced to find alternatives in the future while having a terrible climate, tens of millions of deaths from air pollution and climate disasters, higher sea level, etc.
And the inimitable Ocean Vuong: "Wait a minute. My imposter syndrome is actually my strength. I don't ever want to be comfortable in positions of power." ceromagazine.com/articles/pet...

Two things I find useful in reframing the concept: this "it's not you it's them" piece: "Imposter syndrome took a fairly universal feeling of discomfort, second-guessing, and mild anxiety in the workplace and pathologized it, especially for women." hbr.org/2021/02/stop...
Here, have some flowers instead.
No deaths on my watch, please!
Finally showed up and thank you!

Oh my, yes, this: "Knowledge is power, and the equitable distribution of knowledge is inseparable from other forms of equality."  -- @@2482, "Orwell's Roses", p. 222.  app.thestorygraph.com/books/7615c4...
I thought I should take a quick peek here. And offer you all some dahlias.
